journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Time-optimal trajectory planning of robot manipulators in point-to-point motion using an indirect method

article-meta.aff: Mechanical Engineering Department, Babol University of Technology, Babol, Iran

author-notes.corresp: *Corresponding author: Mechanical Engineering Department, Babol University of Technology, Babol, Iran. email: navvab.kashiri@gmail.com

article-meta.issue-title: INCLUDES A SPECIAL SECTION ON ADVANCED MATERIALS ENGINEERING: SELECTED PAPERS FROM THE INDO-AUSTRIAN SYMPOSIUM 2010

abstract.p: In this study, an iterative method for computing the time-optimal point-to-point control of robot manipulators is studied, subject to limits on the actuator torques and actuator jerks. This method uses the indirect solution of an open-loop optimal control problem so that the optimal control problem is translated to a non-linear two-point boundary value problem (TPBVP). Since there are many difficulties in finding the switching points and solving the TPBVP, a simple iterative method is proposed. This method is based on solving the minimum-energy problem without the necessity of finding the switching point. So, the resultant TPBVP can be solved using the usual algorithms. In addition, since the solution of the TPBVPs is sensitive to the initial guess, a simple procedure for making proper initial guesses is introduced. Furthermore, since the inverse kinematic of redundant manipulators is an ill-posed problem, the general form for boundary conditions corresponding to the final time is considered. In addition, it is shown that the proposed method has no sensitivity for specifying the time-optimal trajectory of manipulators that may contain singular arcs.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Since the ability of manipulators to perform a task in minimum time is desirable, the time-optimal control of manipulators has attracted great interest for decades. The time-optimal control for manipulators leads to the problem of discontinuous actuator torques. These discontinues in actuator torques cause severe vibration on actuators, which leads to increased robot failure. Thus, eliminating the torque discontinuities can prolong the life span of the actuators and the robot. Therefore, inclusion of the limit on the rate of actuator torques (actuator jerks) is necessary.

The problem of minimum time point-to-point control of manipulators has been studied by several researchers. Geering et al. [1] calculated the time-optimal trajectories for a two-link manipulator with arbitrary fixed initial and final positions. Meier and Bryson [2] modified the steepest descent method of optimal programming to find time-optimal switch times for bang–bang control systems. They applied aswitch time optimization (STO) algorithm to a two-link manipulator with two control inputs. Willigenburg and Loop [3] presented a numerical procedure to compute time-optimal solutions for non-linear systems that are linear in control and have fixed initial and final states and bounded controls. Fotouhi and Szyszkowski [4, 5] presented a numerical procedure to compute non-singular, time-optimal solutions for non-linear systems that have fixed initialand final states and that are linear and bounded in controls. Apart from the fact that the jerk constraint is not considered in the above-mentioned studies, applying these methods has too much computational complexity for systems that have several control inputs. In addition to indirect methods, direct methods have been investigated in many different studies. Diehl et al. [6] surveyed numerical approaches to solve non-linear optimal control problems in robotics without considering jerk constraints. Bianco and Piazzi [7] presented a direct approach to obtain a minimum-time cubic spline trajectory for manipulator point-to-multipoint operations subject to constraints given by limited joint torques and torque derivatives, although the computational cost of this method wasrelatively too much.

Time-optimal path planning of manipulators has been investigated in many studies. Bobrow et al. [8] proposed a method for time-optimal control of serial non-redundant manipulators along a specified path, and many researchers have developed this method, for example, Ghasemi and Sadigh [9]. Ma and Watanabe [10] proposed a method to solve the time-optimal trajectory planning of serial redundant manipulators by using the phase-plane analysis and linear programming technique. Constantinescu and Croft [11] presented a method for determining time-optimal path-constrained trajectories with jerk constraints, using the flexible tolerance method. Mattmüller and Gisler [12] presented a near time-optimal and jerk-constrained trajectory planar. Macfarlane and Croft [13] implemented an online method for obtaining smooth, jerk-bounded trajectories. In order to obtain the optimal trajectories in point-to-point motion, they chose the straight-line motion in task space since it is most suitable for industrial manipulator point-to-point operations [13].

The work presented here is an extension to the method studied in [14], and the open-loop time-optimal point-to-point control of manipulators is investigated subject to actuator torque limits. The necessary conditions for optimality are derived from Pontryagin's minimum principle [15–17]. The obtained equations lead to a non-linear two-point boundary value problem (TPBVP) that is usually hard to solve. Chen and Desrochers [14] added an energy term in the performance index to provide a non-singular optimal control problem, which leads to a standard TPBVP, and the time-optimal solution is obtained by decreasing the weight of energy term. Therefore, in comparison to the majority of other previous work, this method has less computational complexities, and it does not require any computation for finding the switching points. Nevertheless, the extra boundary condition, which is required because the final time is unknown, makes the resultant TPBVP too hard to solve for complex systems. Since solutions of the minimum-energy problem and minimum-time–energy problem are exactly the same if the final times of these problems are equal, the effect of decreasing the energy term value of the minimum-time–energy problem is the same as decreasing the final time of the minimum-energy problem [14]. Therefore, by considering that the minimum-time–energy solution converges to a time-optimal solution by decreasing the energy term value of this problem [14], the minimum-energy solution converges to a time-optimal solution by decreasing the final time of the minimum-energy problem. Hence, an iterative procedure based on solving the minimum-energy problem is considered, and the final time of this problem is decreased to some extent; this is similar to that proposed in [18] for determining the maximum payload. Therefore, since this extra boundary condition is not required, the solution of the resulting TPBVP has less computational complexity, and in comparison to previous indirect methods, the proposed iterative method can solve the time-optimal problem of more complex systems. In addition, a simple procedure is introduced to apply the jerk constraint so that no significant calculations are required for considering this constraint. Therefore, this method has less computational complexities than previous work.

In addition, as redundant manipulators have no unique final posture for a final point and the boundary conditions that correspond to the final time are not sufficient in number, the simple form of the boundary conditions that is usually considered in this sort of problems is not utilizable. For suppressing this ill-posed problem, the general form of the boundary conditions of manipulators is considered. At the end, three numerical simulations are presented. It should be noted that the resulting TPBVP can be solved using the usual algorithms such as shooting and collocation. In this work, a residual control-based collocation method [19], resulting in a piece of Matlab software called bvp6c, is applied to solve the TPBVP.

sec.title: 2.1. Problem statement
sec.p: A fully actuated n-link serial manipulator, which is supposed to move its end-effector from the initial position to the final point in a minimum time, is considered. The joint torques, when flexibilities and friction are neglected, can be evaluated by means of the manipulator dynamic equation in the following form [20, 21] (1)q = [q1, ..., qn]T∈ℜn indicates the vector of the joint variables of the manipulator where qi is the ith joint variable of the manipulator (i = 1,…, n). M, g, Γ, u, and C are, respectively, the generalized mass matrix (M∈ℜn×n), vector of gravity torques (g∈ℜn), actuator torque coefficient matrix (Γ ∈ ℜn×n), the vector of actuator forces (u ∈ℜn), and the tensor ofChristoffel symbols (C ∈ℜn×n×n), which is definedas (2)
The actuator limits, including torques and jerks limits, can be chosen arbitrarily and they belong to the feasible sets (3) (4)

sec.title: 2.2. Optimal control problems
sec.p: The problem is to determine the admissible control inputs u ∈ U, where U is the set of the admissible control inputs (3), so that the dynamic system described by the differential equation (5)is transferred from the initial state at initial time (t0) of (6)to an admissible final state at final time (tf) of (7)such that the following performance index is minimized (8)with respect to state vector functions X(t) and control input functions u(t). For a mechanical system, e.g. robots, equation (5) can be written in such a form that the first and second half of the state vector, X(t), represent the positions and velocities of the degrees of freedom of the system, respectively.

The indirect method, which is based on the calculus of variations, has been applied here to solve the optimal control problem. By considering the first variation of the cost function J with dynamic constraints adjoined in the manner of the performance index (L(X(t), u(t),t)), the necessary conditions for optimality are derived. In this method, by introducing the vector of adjoint variables P= [p1T p2T]T = [p11,…, p1n, p21,…, p2n]T ∈ℜ2n, the Hamiltonian function of the system can be presented as (9)
According to Pontryagin's minimum principle [15–17], the necessary conditions for optimality are (10) (11) (12)

The problem given by equations (10) and (11), by considering n input control equations (12), is a set of 4n first-order ordinary differential equations that need 4n conditions to be solved. By considering the 2n known initial states X0 in equation (6) and the 2n final states Xf in equation (7), the required conditions are completed.

As noted previously, the presented method is based on the minimum-energy problem. Thus, the desired fixed final time performance index is (13)where R∈ℜn×n is a symmetric, positive semi-definite weighting matrix that expresses the weights of the input torques in the cost function. In this work, the energy weighting matrix is considered to be a diagonal matrix (R= (ε1,...,εn))

Since the TPBVPs are sensitive to the initial guess, a simple procedure is presented to make a proper initial guess for solving the TPBVP. In order to make the proper initial guess, an approximate linear system is considered, and the corresponding optimal trajectory of this linear system is obtained using the analytical method mentioned in [17]. Then, using the solution of this approximate system, the proper initial guess is obtained by applying another iterative algorithm. If the system is considered as a linear and time-varying plant as Ẋ(t) = A(t)X(t) + B(t)u(t), by considering the minimum-energy cost function of equation (13) and the boundary conditions given by equations (6) and (7), the optimal states and controls are obtained using the analytical method presented in [17]. This method is based on assuming the vector of the adjoint variables to be (14)

Here, this method is summarized to a three-step numerical method (considering A∈ℜ2n×2n and B∈ℜ2n×2n).
Solve the following ordinary differential equations (ODEs)
(15)

by considering the final values to be (16)where I is the identity matrix of 2n-dimensional space and Xf is the final states in equation (7). Since Y(tf) is symmetric, the mentioned equations are a set of n(2n+3) first-order equations, which can be solved using Euler or Runge–Kutta methods.
Compute the optimal states by solving the following ODEs by considering the initial states in equation (6) and the solution of Y(t) and Z(t) from the previous step
(17)
Calculate the optimal adjoint variables using equation (14).

sec.title: 2.3. Manipulator equations
sec.p:
By defining the state vector as X=[ x1T x2T ]2=[ qT q˙T ]T∈ℜ2n, the dynamic equations are rewritten in the form (18)where W = M-1. For solving the resulting TPBVP of the indirect optimal control is too difficult; it is useful to create an iterative procedure to get the solution of the original system from a simple linear one. Therefore, it is helpful to represent equation (18) in the form (19)where
et = [1,...,1]T∈ℜn, W¯=W(x1) , and C¯=C(x¯) . Therefore, the system is a set of 2n first-order linear equations for γ = 0 and the system is the mentioned manipulator (original system) for γ = 1. By substituting equations (13) and (19) into equations (9), (11, and (12), the adjoint differential equations and control input equations (u∞∈ℜn) are rewritten in the form (20) (21)where ei is the ith column (or row) of the identity matrix of n-dimensional space. Since the actuator torques are usually bounded (u∈ U), the control input equations should be modified to (22)where ui∞=–p2TWΓR–1ei. In addition, it is fully clear that equation (10) is the same as equation (19).

sec.title: 2.4. Minimum time calculations
sec.p:
After generating the required equations (19) to (22) and boundary conditions (6) and (7), which lead to a TPBVP, the minimum time taken by the manipulator to move the end-effector from an initial point to a final point is obtained by performing the following processes.
Creating the initial guess: the minimum-energy solution for γ =0 is obtained using the three-step method, equations (14) to (17), for a sample time (tfinitial). Then, the TPBVP is solved for more γ using the solution of previous γ values as the initial guess, and this procedure is continued until γ=1 and the initial guess (Sinitial) is created. Since this three-step method is not capable of considering torque constraint, the sample time should be chosen to belong enough so that the actuator torques does not exceed the torque bounds. It should be noted that the rate of increasing γ depends on the complexity of the system, although this quality is recommended to be logarithmic.
Minimum time calculation: the time-optimal solution is obtained by applying the algorithm presented in Fig. 1. As noted previously, this algorithm is based on decreasing the final time of the minimum-energy problem. Hence, two loops are considered. The inner loop, which decreases the final time, is continued until the solution of the minimum-energy problem for the decreased final time is accessible; and the outer loop, which reduces the measure of the decreasing final time in the inner loop, is continued until the measure of decreasing time becomes less than the accuracy of the minimum time solution. Therefore, after several inner iterations, the outer loop is iterated and the measure of the decreasing final time is reduced. Therefore, after more iterations, eventually the measure of the reducing time becomes less than the accuracy of the minimum time solution and the calculation is finished. In addition, since the actuators do not have the same efficiency and ability, the energy weighting matrix should be modified in iterations so that the full ability of actuators can be used based on the relation between actuator energies and actuator jerks.
Fig. 1
Flowchart of the minimum time calculation

In this flowchart, µ, δ, and β>1 are the accuracy of the minimum time calculation, the measure of the decreasing final time in the inner loop, and the reduction rate of the measure of the decreasing final time, respectively. The index of the outer loop and the index of the inner loop are i and n, respectively. S is the initial guess for solving the TPBVP and is obtained from the solution of the previous iteration. Λ is the vector of the absolute maximum jerk of the actuators. The vector of the actuator jerks at any instant is calculated through the numeric variation of the vector of actuator torques (23)Thus, Λ is defined in the following form (24)In order to modify the energy weighting matrix (R), the nearly inverse relation between the weight of actuator energies and actuator jerks is used (25)In summary, the loop index (n) decrease the final time by δ(0) until no solution of the TPBVP with desired accuracy is accessible for the decreased final time. When the iterations of this loop are accomplished, the loop index (i) reduces δ(0) to δ(1) = δ(0)/β, and the iterations of the loop index (n) is restarted for δ(1). This procedure is continued until the ith outer loop, when µ> δ(i) occurs and the final time with a proper accuracy is obtained. In addition, in order to use the whole possible energy of the actuators, the energy weighting matrix R is revised using equations (23) to (25) during iterations.

It should be noted that, although the solution of the presented algorithm is independent of the optional parameters of the algorithm (tfinitial, δ(0), and β), they affect the rate of the convergence of the algorithm to some extent.
Although the sample time (tfinitial) should be chosen to be long enough to create a proper initial guess, the computational time may increase to a great extent if the sample time is chosen to be excessively long.
If a large value of β is chosen, the number of inner iterations is increased, while a rather small value for this measure may increase the number of outer iterations to some extent. Hence, the value β∈[3, 9] is recommended.
The choice of the initial value of δ, δ(0) has no significant effect on the convergence of the algorithm, unless a very large or small value is chosen for this parameter, which increases the number of outer or inner iterations, respectively. The recommended value of this parameter is δ(0)∈[tfinitial/β2, tfinitial/β].

In addition, in order to decrease computations, there is no need to use the modification of the weighting matrix of energy at the first loop index (i), i=0. Inaddition, since the final time is unknown and during the algorithm, this time is varied, it is recommended to transform the time interval into a normalized one. Therefore, the change of variable of t = η(tf - t0) + t0, t0≤ t ≤ tf, 0 ≤ η ≤ is given. Therefore the state space equations will be (26)

sec.title: 2.5. General form for boundary conditions at the final time
sec.p: The boundary conditions in the following general form are considered (27)
By considering these k final constraints, the following equations are required to provide the 2n necessary conditions at the final time [16] (28)
Equations (27) and (28) include 2n + k equations and k unknown coefficients di (i = 1,…,k). By solving this set of equations, 2n boundary conditions in the final time are obtained.

As mentioned, in order to make the initial guess using the three-step method, equations (14) to (17), the final states are required, but they are not known in a general form. For suppressing this difficulty, an arbitrary final state should be chosen so that the terminal conditions (27) are satisfied. This choice specifies the final elbow orientation while the exact values have no effect on the final results. Hence, if singularity during motion is not desired, the final states should be chosen so that the elbow orientation is the same as the initial one.

sec.title: 2.6. Jerk constraints
sec.p: The actuator jerk constraints are given in equation (4). In order to satisfy the jerk bound at the beginning of the motion, the actuator torques should be increased slightly. Hence, by applying the following torque bound, this goal is satisfied. (29)where ur is the required torque to keep the equilibrium of the manipulator at the initial time. It is obtained by solving equation (18) for the initial state. Therefore, the total bound of the torques is defined as (30)where ∩ shows the intersection of bounds. Therefore, by applying the new torque bound of equation (30), the actuator torques cannot change rapidly at the start of motion. However, applying this torque bound entails that the actuators use the maximum permissible torque rate at the beginning of motion, and using equation (25) for modifying the energy weighting matrix has no effect until the actuator jerks exceed their admissible levels. Hence, this partof the variation of the torques in where the actuators use the saturation of jerk bound should be recognized as (31)
Therefore, actuator jerks should be computed in t∈[tsitf] instead of t ∈ [t0 tf] for computing Λ from equation (24).

In order to keep the jerk constraint during motion, the final time should be decreased until the actuator jerks do not exceed the actuator jerk limitation. In addition, in order to use the full ability of the actuators the modification of the weighting matrix of energy should be carried out using equation (25) by considering the following vector (Ψ) instead of Λ. (32)where

Accordingly, the proposed flowchart of Fig. 1 ischanged to the flowchart of Fig. 2. As shown in Fig. 2, in order to continue the loop index (n), besides the existence of solution, the actuator torque rates should not exceed the bounds. In addition to the non-existence of the solution, an unauthorized amount of actuator jerks reduces the measure of the decreasing final time in the inner loop. Fig. 2
Flowchart of the minimum time calculation in the presence of the jerk constraint

sec.title: 3 NUMERICAL SIMULATIONS
sec.p: For all simulations given in this section, sample time, the accuracy of the minimum time calculation, the initial measure of the decreasing final time, and the reduction rate of the measure of the decreasing final time are chosen as tfinitial=5s, μ = 10-5,δ(0) = 0.5, and β=6, respectively.

sec.title: 3.1. Case 1: A planar two-link serial manipulator
sec.p:
In order to show the accuracy of the proposed method, a planar two-link serial manipulator is considered. The time-optimal problem of this case has been discussed in [1], [3], and [4]. The physical parameters of this manipulator and actuator torque limits are given in Table 1. In addition to these parameters, the link offsets and twist angles are zero (αi = 0, di = 0 for i = 1, 2) and the mass centre of links are middle ones. Table 1
Physical parameters of a two-link manipulator [4]. mi and Mi are the mass of the ith link and concentrated mass of the end of the ith link, respectively
Link Mass (kg) Moment of inertia (kg m2) Length (m) Rotation angle (rad) Torque bound (N m)
1 m1 = 29.58 M1 = 0 I1 = 0.416739 l1=0.4 q1 U1∈ [- 25 & 25]
2 m2 = 15.00 M2 = 6 I2 = 0.205625 l2=0.25 q2 U2 ∈ [ - 9 9]

This problem is investigated for two boundary conditions. The first one does not include singular arcs, while the other one contains a singular arc to demonstrate the ability of the proposed method for solving the singular problems.

sec.title: 3.1.1. Condition A
sec.p: The boundary conditions are (33)

By applying the proposed algorithm, the minimum time is calculated. The time-optimal state trajectories and actuators torque are shown in Fig. 3. Fig. 3
Time-optimal state trajectories and actuator torques versus non-dimensional time: condition A

The optimal traversal time is tf = 1.08261 s and the optimal final times according to [1], [3], and [4] aretf = 1.085 s, 1.085 s, and 1.083378 s, respectively. The results are obtained after 34 iterations. As shown in Fig. 4(a) (the error is defined by (tfith iteration− tffinal)/tffinal), after 14 iterations, no effective change happens,while the computational time is increased (the computations are carried out using an Entertainment PC with a Pentium 3, CPU 2.26 GHz, RAM 1.5 GB). In addition, as shown in Fig. 4(b), the energy coefficient of the first actuator is decreased more than the energy coefficient of the second actuator. In other words, the energy coefficient of the first actuator should be less than the other one to use its whole ability. Fig. 4
(a) Computional time and error versus iteration and (b) weighting matrix coefficients versus iteration

sec.title: 3.1.1. Condition B
sec.p: For this case, the boundary conditions are (34)

The time-optimal state trajectories and actuator torques are shown in Fig. 5. Fig. 5
Time-optimal state trajectories and actuator torques versus non-dimensional time: condition B
The optimal traversal time is tf = 0.97558 s and the optimal final time according to equations [1] and [3] is tf = 0.9755 s.

Comparing the results of the proposed method with past works show that the results of the proposed method are in good agreement with past work, which confirms the accuracy and ability of the proposed method. In addition, solving the singular cases is the same as solving non-singular ones, and this method has no sensitivity to singularity.

sec.title: 3.2. Case 2: A planar three-link serial manipulator (simple redundant manipulator)
sec.p:
The time-optimal point-to-point motion of a simple redundant manipulator, as shown in Fig. 6, is studied to investigate the effect of changing the point-to-point motion to straight-line motion. Fig. 6
Planar three-link serial manipulator

The time-optimal trajectory planning of this manipulator along a straight-line path has been studied in [10], and the physical parameters, as well as the initial condition and the final point, are taken from this reference. The initial states are as follows (35)
The final posture of arm is so that the end-effector should be at the final point while the joints are in inaction status. The final point is (36)

The physical parameters of the manipulator and actuator limits are given in Table 2. Table 2
Physical parameters of a three-link manipulator [10] and actuator limits
Length of links l1 = l2 = l3 = 1 m
Mass of links m1 = m2 = m3 = 10
Torque limits -10 Nm ≤ τi ≤ 10 Nm i = 1,2,3
Low jerk limits (LJLs) –10Nm/s≤τ˙i≤10Nm/si=1,2,3
High jerk limits (HJLs) –100Nm/s≤τ˙i≤100Nm/si=1,2,3

By applying the proposed method, the optimal trajectories and minimum time is calculated. The time history of the optimal states, including joints velocities and joints positions, with and without considering jerk constraints are shown in Fig. 7. Fig. 7
Time-optimal state trajectories versus non-dimensional time (-: unlimited jerk, -: HJL, - -: LJL)

As mentioned previously, in order to make the initial guess, a final posture should be considered. So, by considering the initial elbow orientation as the final elbow orientation, the final states are chosen (37)
As expected, the optimal terminal posture of the manipulator ([q1, q2, q3] = [0.34, −2.86, 2.05]) is not the same as the assumption (equation (37)), although the elbow orientation is the same.

The actuator torques with and without considering jerk constraints beside the actuators jerks in the presence of jerk constraints are shown in Fig. 8. Fig. 8
Actuator torques and jerks versus non-dimensional time (-: unlimited jerk, -: HJL, - -: LJL); the jerks of HJL are numbered on the right-hand y-axix and the jerks of LJL are numbered on the left-hand y-axis

Without considering jerk constraint, the optimal traversal time is tf = 1.72934 s, while this time is tf = 1.84 s in straight-line motion. The traversal times in the presence of a high jerk limit (HJL) and a low jerk limit (LJL) are tf = 1.79370 s and tf = 2.75162 s, respectively.

sec.title: 3.3. Case 3: A PUMA 560 manipulator
sec.p: Finally, a PUMA 560 manipulator has been chosen as a well-known spatial manipulator. The initial and final joint velocities are zero, and the initial and final postures are (38) (39)

The kinematic and dynamic parameters of this manipulator, such as the Denavit–Hartenberg (DH) parameters and link parameters, are taken from Armstrong et al. [22], and the actuator limits are chosen to be the same as [7]. All of these parameters are listed in Tables 3, 4, and 5. Table 3

By applying the proposed method, the minimum time and optimal trajectories with and without considering jerk constraints are calculated. It should be noted that, since the last three links of the robot (wrist of the manipulator) act nearly independent of the first three links, the energy matrix modification of these two parts should be performed independently.

The optimal traversal times with and without considering jerk constraints are tf = 0.88804 s and tf = 0.64969 s, respectively. The time history of the joint positions and the actuator torques are shown in Figs 9 and 10, respectively. The other figures, including joint velocities and actuator jerks, are not presented for the sake of brevity. Fig. 9
Time-optimal angular positions versus non-dimensional time (-: unlimited jerk, - -: limited jerk)
Fig. 10
Actuator torques versus non-dimensional time (-: unlimited jerk, -.-: limited jerk)

sec.title: 4 CONCLUSION
sec.p: In this paper, a time-optimal control method for point-to-point motion of manipulators was proposed subject to actuator torque and jerk limits. This method is an indirect open-loop control method based on Pontryagin's minimum principle. It was shown that the proposed method is able to solve problems that may contain singular arcs. In addition, the general form of the boundary conditions corresponding to the final time is considered to cover the ill-posed problem of redundant manipulators. Therefore, the proposed method can be applied for solving theinverse kinematic of redundant manipulators. In addition, due to the fact that this problem leads to a TPBVP which is very sensitive to the initial guess, a simple procedure for generating the proper initial guess was mentioned. Then, an iterative method for computing the optimal time was proposed based on decreasing the final time of the minimum-energy problem. Finally, some simulations were performed to demonstrate the accuracy and efficiency of the proposed method.

sec.title: FUNDING
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
